messageBody:
> > I had some problems when I started to use JUnit, a
> > week ago.

> Welcome!

lol!

> > After some research, I figure out that the
> > problem was the J2ME sandbox. I created my first
> test
> > case to test a simple class used by a MIDlet, and
> it
> > didn't work because it's not possible to do
> something
> > like that:
> >
> > public static void main (String args[])
> > {
> > The J2ME code...
> > }
> Sounds frustrating. I'm afraid I don't know a lot
> about J2ME, but I
> know a fair bit about running JUnit. If J2ME
> doesn't run code within a
> "main" method, can you give a short example of how
> J2ME code running
> inside a sandbox looks? Thanks,
>
> David Saff

It's very similar to a servlet or applet, but in the
micro edition, our "let" is the midlet. The
aplications must have a derived class of the MIDlet
class (it is part of the J2ME core) and implement the
abstract methods startApp, pauseApp and destroyApp.
The device itself, when receive the apropriate user's
input, call the startApp, so the program begins. I
don't remember very well of applet implementation, but
i think that there's a method called start with the
same propose. The fact is that i can't test my J2ME
classes because i believe that the JUnit try to use
them inside a main method. I believe so because the
kind of Error (Error, not Exception) that is throwed
during the tests is the same that occurs when i tried
to use main method a long time ago, just to test the
J2ME sandbox. I already tried to use the J2MEUnit
(that looks to don't have the problem), but there are
many other problems with this framework, for example,
i think that 40% of assert methods didn't existe
there, like assertFalse or assertEquals. I used
assertTrue(!...) and others tricks, but I still having
problems with another things...
